Title: Prove that If $f$ is polynomial function of even degree $n$ with always $f\geq0$ then $f+f'+f''+\cdots+f^{(n)}\geq 0$.
Content:
I can't solve this problem: Suppose $f$ is polynomial function of even degree $n$ with always $f\geq0$. Prove that
$f+f'+f''+\cdots+f^{(n)}\geq 0$.
AcceptedAnswer:
Let $g=f+f'+\cdots+f^{(n)}$ and let $h(x)=e^{-x}g(x)$. Note that $f^{(n+1)}=0$, so
$$h'(x)=e^{-x}(g'(x)-g(x))=-e^{-x}f(x)\le 0,$$ 
i.e. $h$ is decrearing on $\mathbb R$.
Since $g$ is a polynomial, $\lim\limits_{x\to+\infty}h(x)=0$. It follows that $h\ge 0$, and hence $g\ge 0$.
